chunks.en: I don't know why, but I'm losing more and more motivation to go to work.
I've been working for almost 10 years, and I feel more and more that going to work is boring, and I'm mentally exhausted.
Especially after the New Year, it's even more boring, and I don't have the energy to go to work ğŸ˜”.
I wonder if anyone else feels this way, and how do you relieve it?

I worked for four years, and I was also very mentally drained. Eventually, I resigned and went motorcycle traveling across most of China. After returning, I spent half a year developing my own product, but no one used it.
Now I've been on a gap year for 10 months, and I don't have any interview opportunities, so I'm starting to get anxious.

chunks.en: Before I resigned, I felt like I was going to die if I kept working this job. Now that I've been on a gap year for so long, I feel like I'm going to die if I don't get this job.
After working for a few years, I realized that nothing I was doing was meaningful, and it was all garbage business logic.
Just scraping by for a living.
I felt this way after working for 1 year, how did you only get sick after 10 years?
Same feeling, work is just exchanging labor for money, unless it's something you really want to do, it can't give you any sense of meaning or value.
I'm more greedy: I just want to lie down, browse my phone, watch TV, read books, and then have someone pay me my salary on time every month ğŸ¶.
It's all like this, I feel like there's no way to relieve it unless you quit, but after you quit, you're very anxious.
Have you ever tried to be motivated at work?
I find it hard to understand.
In my perception, going to work has never been fun, it's the law.
I got sick as soon as I started working, so I only looked for companies with 9-to-5, double weekends, and no overtime. The salary is a bit lower, but it's not as tiring.
@jiahee45 Move the upper right corner of the comment and the thank you button will be displayed.
When I first started working: Work is great, I earn my own money and spend it, I can totally buy a lot of things I wanted to buy before but couldn't afford.
When I have just enough money for a down payment: I start to worry, what can I do with the few b's in my hand?

After the housing price starts to fall, I'm not in a hurry to buy a house and continue to save money for a while: Going to work is starting to get boring, but I can still hold on, money is just a string of numbers to me.
When I've saved nearly 2 million: Holy shit, I can live off the interest, why do I have to go to this crappy job, damn it.
Especially this year, the company is doing some kind of job level evaluation, everyone participates, and if you don't answer well, you'll be demoted.

Throughout: A worker's soul works, if I don't work, I don't know what I can do, I'm also old, if I really gap for a year or two, I'll say goodbye to being a programmer completely, I'll just scrape by.
Continue to accumulate, so that I have more choices when I really graduate in the future.
Not only you.
Especially when I have to work overtime today.
Thinking that even the New Year holiday is borrowed.
It's just boring.
The general's favor can never be repaid.
The main reason I'm not motivated is that I'm always working on big requirements. I still prefer to slowly work on some procedural, mindless requirements.
